TypeSignature.Value: .class public auto ansi beforefieldinit HtmlInputCheckBox extends System.Web.UI.HtmlControls.HtmlInputControl implements class System.Web.UI.IPostBackDataHandler
Public Class HtmlInputCheckBox Inherits HtmlInputControl Implements IPostBackDataHandler
type HtmlInputCheckBox = class inherit HtmlInputControl interface IPostBackDataHandler

Docs.summary: Allows programmatic access to the HTML element on the server.

remarks.format:
## Remarks Use the <xref:System.Web.UI.HtmlControls.HtmlInputCheckBox> control to allow the user to select a `true` or `false` state. To determine whether the control is selected, use the <xref:System.Web.UI.HtmlControls.HtmlInputCheckBox.Checked%2A> property. The <xref:System.Web.UI.HtmlControls.HtmlInputCheckBox> control provides a <xref:System.Web.UI.HtmlControls.HtmlInputCheckBox.ServerChange> event that is raised when the <xref:System.Web.UI.HtmlControls.HtmlInputCheckBox.Checked%2A> property changes values between posts to the server. This allows you to create an event handler that performs a custom set of instructions each time the event is raised.
> [!NOTE] > The <xref:System.Web.UI.HtmlControls.HtmlInputCheckBox> control does not post back to the server when it is clicked. You must provide another control on the Web page that supports posting to the server, such as an <xref:System.Web.UI.HtmlControls.HtmlButton> control, to send the state of the control back to the server.
For a list of initial property values for an instance of <xref:System.Web.UI.HtmlControls.HtmlInputCheckBox>, see the <xref:System.Web.UI.HtmlControls.HtmlInputCheckBox.%23ctor%2A> constructor.
## Examples The following code example demonstrates a set of simple responses to users selecting from a group of <xref:System.Web.UI.HtmlControls.HtmlInputCheckBox> controls.
[!code-aspx-csharp[Classic HtmlInputCheckBox Example#1](~/samples/snippets/csharp/VS_Snippets_WebNet/Classic HtmlInputCheckBox Example/cs/sourcecs.aspx#1)] [!code-aspx-vb[Classic HtmlInputCheckBox Example#1](~/samples/snippets/visualbasic/VS_Snippets_WebNet/Classic HtmlInputCheckBox Example/VB/sourcevb.aspx#1)]

remarks.format:
## Remarks Use this property to determine whether the <xref:System.Web.UI.HtmlControls.HtmlInputCheckBox> control is selected. This property can also be used to programmatically set the state of the <xref:System.Web.UI.HtmlControls.HtmlInputCheckBox> control.
## Examples The following code example demonstrates a set of responses to users selecting from a group of <xref:System.Web.UI.HtmlControls.HtmlInputCheckBox> controls.

remarks.format:
## Remarks The <xref:System.Web.UI.HtmlControls.HtmlInputCheckBox.OnPreRender%2A> method overrides the base <xref:System.Web.UI.Control.OnPreRender%2A> method. <xref:System.Web.UI.HtmlControls.HtmlInputCheckBox.OnPreRender%2A> is used primarily by control developers.
## Examples The following code example demonstrates how to override the <xref:System.Web.UI.HtmlControls.HtmlInputCheckBox.OnPreRender%2A> method in a custom server control so that a `Title` attribute is added to each <xref:System.Web.UI.HtmlControls.HtmlInputCheckBox> control.

Protected Overridable Sub OnServerChange (e As EventArgs)
abstract member OnServerChange : EventArgs -> unit override this.OnServerChange : EventArgs -> unit

Docs.summary: Raises the event. This method allows you to handle the event directly.

remarks.format:
## Remarks This event is raised when the Web page is submitted to the server and the <xref:System.Web.UI.HtmlControls.HtmlInputCheckBox> control changes state from the previous post. This method allows you to override the base implementation and provide a custom handler for the event.
> [!NOTE] > The control must have view state enabled for the <xref:System.Web.UI.HtmlControls.HtmlInputCheckBox.ServerChange> event to work correctly.
Raising an event invokes the event handler through a delegate. For more information, see [Handling and Raising Events](~/docs/standard/events/index.md).
The <xref:System.Web.UI.HtmlControls.HtmlInputCheckBox.OnServerChange%2A> method also allows derived classes to handle the event without attaching a delegate. This is the preferred technique for handling the event in a derived class.
## Examples The following code example demonstrates how to specify and code a handler for the <xref:System.Web.UI.HtmlControls.HtmlInputCheckBox.ServerChange> event.
[!code-aspx-csharp[Classic HtmlInputCheckBox.ServerChange Example#1](~/samples/snippets/csharp/VS_Snippets_WebNet/Classic HtmlInputCheckBox.ServerChange Example/CS/sourcecs.aspx#1)] [!code-aspx-vb[Classic HtmlInputCheckBox.ServerChange Example#1](~/samples/snippets/visualbasic/VS_Snippets_WebNet/Classic HtmlInputCheckBox.ServerChange Example/VB/sourcevb.aspx#1)]

block.para: When overriding in a derived class, be sure to call the base class's method so that registered delegates receive the event.

> [!NOTE] > The control must have view state enabled for the <xref:System.Web.UI.HtmlControls.HtmlInputCheckBox.ServerChange> event to work correctly.
